prop.head.headtext: Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: Three classes of fiduciary or “trust” relationships exist:
the traditional fiduciary relationships such as those between directors and corporations, solicitor and client, etc.;

fiduciary relationships arising out of specific circumstances where the existence of a fiduciary relationship is a matter of fact (e.g., where the employee is in a position of importance and has been made privy to confidential business information belonging to the company);

“fiduciary” relationships in which the label is merely facilitative in achieving what appears to be the appropriate result (this situation arises where certain remedies, deemed appropriate in certain cases, would not be available unless a fiduciary relationship was present).[1]

If a joint activity agreement is established, the parties are generally held to have established a fiduciary relationship creating an obligation of trust and confidence.[2] In the trial decision of LAC Minerals Ltd. v. International Corona Resources Ltd.,[3] the court held that LAC had a duty not to use the information in question to the detriment of Corona or to use the information for its own benefit regardless of any detrimental consequence to Corona. The Court of Appeal further held that, in the mining industry, a fiduciary relationship may come into being when the parties seriously negotiate a joint venture.[4] Therefore, once LAC made the decision to approach Corona and commence negotiations, it embarked upon a course of events which imposed on it a duty to Corona that could not be shirked without Corona's consent. (An interesting issue which was not raised in this case was whether Corona had given LAC its implied consent to use the information by making no protest when it learned that LAC was bidding on the Williams' property.)
LAC Minerals Ltd. v. International Corona Resources Ltd. (1989), 61 D.L.R. (4th) 14, at p. 28, [1989] 2 S.C.R. 574.

Kaye v. Smitherman, 225 F.2d 583 (10th Cir., 1955), cert. denied 350 U.S. 913 (1955); Abode Properties Ltd. v. Schickedanz Bros. Ltd. (1999), 254 A.R. 91 (Q.B.). But see Terra Energy Ltd. v. Kilborn Engineering Alberta Ltd. (1999), 170 D.L.R. (4th) 405, [1999] 6 W.W.R. 483, 195 W.A.C. 101 (Alta. C.A.), leave to appeal to S.C.C. refused 220 W.A.C. 399n, 255 A.R. 399n, 153 N.R. 193n.
